title: Writer Julian Fellowes Prepares ‘Downton Abbey’ for the Big Screen
text:
Julian Fellowes spent three years figuring out how to kill Sybil, but he killed Matthew quickly.

Those who don’t know Matthew and Sybil and how they met their ends are not those whom Lord Fellowes, a 70-year-old member of the House of Lords, had in mind when writing his latest movie, “Downton Abbey.”

“I don’t think there would be a reason to go to see the movie of a TV show that you had not followed,” he says.

Millions followed. Drawn to the lives of the Crawley family and their staff and Lord Fellowes’ commitment to accurately depicting life in a British estate in the early 20th century, the “Downtown Abbey” TV series was a hit on both sides of the Atlantic. In the U.S., more advance tickets sold for “Downton Abbey” on Fandango the day they went on sale than any other drama this year. The movie opens widely on Friday.

If “Downton” fans turn out in force, Lord Fellowes says, there may be another film. But he also has felt fans’ ire. Some are still sour about deaths in the family. Lord Fellowes says when the actors who portrayed them decided to leave the show, death was the only believable exit.

“Family who are leaving must die because there’s nothing else for them,” he says. “There’s no other reason why you never see them again.”

We asked Lord Fellowes about the servants and family members who made it to the movie. Here are edited excerpts:

In what ways did you think it was essential for “Downtown Abbey” to be accurate?

I think if you try to get all the details right and you talk to enough people who remember that life—which there were when I was much younger—you can imbue it with a kind of reality that seems believable to people who maybe don’t know about that way of life and certainly may not approve of it, but when they watch it, they can see how it worked. They can understand how people lived like that. Whereas when you start to get all the details wrong, it doesn’t feel believable. It doesn’t feel truthful.

The cast of the ‘Downton Abbey’ film includes, from left, Elizabeth McGovern, Harry Hadden-Paton, Laura Carmichael, Hugh Bonneville and Michael Fox. Photo: Jaap Buitendijk/Focus Features

If truth and accuracy are so important for depicting this time and this way of life, why go with fiction and not nonfiction, like “The Crown?”

The only problem with nonfiction is that I feel that you are limited by what really happened to those people. I think “The Crown” has been successful because they have chosen one of the only people on Earth to whom major events are constantly happening. But most people don’t have lives like that. They have periods of industry, periods of activity, and then lulls, periods when practically nothing happens, and you can’t afford that in a drama.

Cast members of the ‘Downton Abbey’ movie include, from left, Lesley Nicol, Sophie McShera, Jim Carter and Phyllis Logan. Photo: Jaap Buitendijk/Focus Features

The “Downton” TV show received criticism for softening the experience of the downstairs staff and that life for them was tougher than portrayed. Is that fair?

Not really. I think that is a modern kind of fixation that everyone downstairs was having a horrible time and everyone was terribly rude to their servants and they all suffered and were having a ghastly time. When I made “Gosford Park,” I had as advisers three ex-servants. All of them had enjoyed their time in service. And they all had funny stories, some of which I pitched for the movie.

It’s a way of life that’s gone and I don’t think it’s a bad state that it’s gone. But realistically it must’ve been livable on a level by pretty well everyone involved or it wouldn’t have gone on for a thousand years.

Are you celebrating an era and its values or documenting an age?

I think it’s more a question of documenting it. I mean there were some aspects of that era that seem quite luxurious in these days of political turbulence that we are living through. And there is a kind of order to the way they lived their lives—as they changed their clothes for dinner, and did the same things again and again. But I wouldn’t really go further than that. I don’t celebrate the injustices in society, the difficulty of social mobility, or the control of the upper classes before the First World War.

Historical accuracy was essential in ‘Downton Abbey,’ Lord Fellowes said, because ‘when you start to get all the details wrong, it doesn’t feel believable.’ Photo: Brad Trent for The Wall Street Journal

The Brief Bio Name: Julian Fellowes

Julian Fellowes What He Does: Screenwriter, actor

Screenwriter, actor How He Got Here: Lord Fellowes created the TV series, “Downton Abbey,” which ran for six seasons. Its upstairs/downstairs premise was similar to that of his screenwriting breakthrough, “Gosford Park” (2001).

Lord Fellowes created the TV series, “Downton Abbey,” which ran for six seasons. Its upstairs/downstairs premise was similar to that of his screenwriting breakthrough, “Gosford Park” (2001). His Big Break: As big a break as Robert Altman hiring him for “Gosford Park,” Lord Fellowes says, was the filmmaker resisting the studio’s urging to bring in a more established name for a rewrite. “That is why I stayed on the picture,” he says. “That’s why I won the Oscar” for a screenplay written directly for the screen.
